comments:
If you have a ManyToOne mapping in a MappedSuperclass and you choose to edit the default joinColumn in the JPA details view you get the following exception:

java.lang.NullPointerException
at org.eclipse.jpt.ui.internal.mappings.details.JoinColumnInRelationshipMappingDialog.getSchema(JoinColumnInRelationshipMappingDialog.java:41)
at org.eclipse.jpt.ui.internal.mappings.details.JoinColumnInRelationshipMappingDialog.getNameTable(JoinColumnInRelationshipMappingDialog.java:45)
at org.eclipse.jpt.ui.internal.mappings.details.AbstractJoinColumnDialog.populateNameCombo(AbstractJoinColumnDialog.java:102)
at org.eclipse.jpt.ui.internal.mappings.details.AbstractJoinColumnDialog.createDialogArea(AbstractJoinColumnDialog.java:79)
at org.eclipse.jpt.ui.internal.mappings.details.JoinColumnDialog.createDialogArea(JoinColumnDialog.java:57)
at org.eclipse.jface.dialogs.Dialog.createContents(Dialog.java:752)
at org.eclipse.jface.window.Window.create(Window.java:426)
at org.eclipse.jface.dialogs.Dialog.create(Dialog.java:1081)
at org.eclipse.jface.window.Window.open(Window.java:785)
at org.eclipse.jpt.ui.internal.mappings.details.JoinColumnComposite.editJoinColumnFromDialog(JoinColumnComposite.java:292)
This bug prevents the user from editing the default joinColumn in the UI on a Many to One in a Mapped Superclass.  The fix is simple and low risk.  Reviewed, tested, and approved.
